content.title: Shock Classification
content.summary: Shock is a life-threatening circulatory failure resulting in inadequate oxygen delivery to tissues. It is classified into four mechanistic categories based on hemodynamic profiles: distributive (vasodilatory), cardiogenic (pump failure), hypovolemic (volume loss), and obstructive (flow obstruction). Proper classification guides specific treatment while initial resuscitation addresses tissue perfusion.
key_points: Shock = inadequate tissue oxygen delivery leading to cellular dysfunction and organ failure
Four categories: Distributive, Cardiogenic, Hypovolemic, Obstructive
Hemodynamic profile (CVP, CO, SVR) distinguishes shock types
Distributive (septic) is most common ICU shock; cardiogenic has highest mortality
Lactate elevation reflects anaerobic metabolism from tissue hypoperfusion
Mixed shock presentations are common; reassess frequently
content.statement: Shock is defined by inadequate tissue perfusion leading to cellular hypoxia, classified by mechanism into distributive, cardiogenic, hypovolemic, and obstructive types, with each requiring distinct hemodynamic interventions guided by clinical and monitored parameters.

explanation.intuition: Think of the circulatory system as a closed loop with a pump (heart), pipes (vessels), and fluid (blood). Shock occurs when: the pump fails (cardiogenic), pipes dilate too much (distributive), fluid leaks out (hypovolemic), or something blocks flow (obstructive). Treatment targets the broken component.
explanation.key_insight: Hemodynamic profiles are the key to classification: low SVR with high CO = distributive; low CO with high filling pressures = cardiogenic; low CO with low filling pressures = hypovolemic; low CO with high JVP but clear lungs = obstructive.
explanation.technical_details: Shock Index (HR/SBP >0.7) suggests hemodynamic compromise. Lactate >2 mmol/L indicates tissue hypoperfusion. Mixed venous O2 saturation <65% reflects increased O2 extraction from inadequate delivery. Echocardiography rapidly distinguishes shock types at bedside.

definitions_glossary.shock: Circulatory failure with inadequate tissue oxygen delivery causing cellular dysfunction
definitions_glossary.distributive_shock: Vasodilatory shock with low SVR; includes septic, anaphylactic, neurogenic
definitions_glossary.cardiogenic_shock: Pump failure with low cardiac output from intrinsic heart dysfunction
definitions_glossary.hypovolemic_shock: Inadequate circulating volume from hemorrhage or fluid loss
definitions_glossary.obstructive_shock: Mechanical obstruction to blood flow (PE, tamponade, tension pneumothorax)
definitions_glossary.cardiac_output: Volume of blood pumped by heart per minute; normal ~5 L/min
definitions_glossary.systemic_vascular_resistance: Resistance to blood flow in systemic circulation
definitions_glossary.central_venous_pressure: Pressure in vena cava/right atrium; estimates preload
definitions_glossary.lactate: Byproduct of anaerobic metabolism; elevated in shock from tissue hypoperfusion
definitions_glossary.shock_index: Heart rate divided by systolic BP; >0.7 suggests hemodynamic compromise
definitions_glossary.mean_arterial_pressure: Average arterial pressure during cardiac cycle; target ≥65 mmHg in shock
definitions_glossary.tissue_hypoxia: Inadequate oxygen delivery to cells causing anaerobic metabolism

pathophysiology.common_pathway: All shock types → inadequate O2 delivery → cellular hypoxia → anaerobic metabolism → lactate production → organ dysfunction → death if untreated

distributive.mechanism: Pathologic vasodilation → low SVR → relative hypovolemia → tissue hypoperfusion

subtypes.septic: Most common ICU shock; cytokine-mediated vasodilation
subtypes.neurogenic: Loss of sympathetic tone from spinal cord injury

distributive.hemodynamics: Low SVR, high CO (initially), low CVP, warm extremities

cardiogenic.mechanism: Pump failure → low CO → tissue hypoperfusion with backup into lungs
cardiogenic.hemodynamics: Low CO, high SVR (compensatory), high CVP/PCWP, cool extremities, pulmonary edema

hypovolemic.mechanism: Inadequate circulating volume → low preload → low CO → tissue hypoperfusion

subtypes.hemorrhagic: Trauma, GI bleeding, ruptured AAA, postpartum hemorrhage

hypovolemic.hemodynamics: Low CO, high SVR, low CVP, collapsed IVC

obstructive.mechanism: Mechanical obstruction prevents cardiac filling or output
obstructive.hemodynamics: Low CO, high SVR, high CVP (except tension pneumo), pulsus paradoxus

laboratory_findings.base_deficit: Negative base excess from metabolic acidosis

hemodynamic_assessment.clinical_exam: JVP, lung sounds, extremity temperature, capillary refill
hemodynamic_assessment.echocardiography: LV/RV function, pericardial effusion, IVC size/collapsibility
hemodynamic_assessment.invasive_monitoring: CVP, arterial line, PA catheter (selective use)

differential_diagnosis: Mixed shock (e.g., sepsis + cardiogenic from sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy)

general_principles.airway_breathing: Secure airway if needed; oxygen; mechanical ventilation as indicated
general_principles.circulation: IV access (large bore, central if needed); fluid resuscitation
general_principles.target_MAP: ≥65 mmHg (may need higher in chronic hypertension)

type_specific_treatment.distributive: Fluids → norepinephrine (first-line vasopressor) → source control (sepsis); epinephrine (anaphylaxis)
type_specific_treatment.cardiogenic: Limit fluids; inotropes (dobutamine, milrinone); vasopressors if needed; revascularization if MI; MCS if refractory
type_specific_treatment.hypovolemic: Aggressive fluid resuscitation; blood products if hemorrhagic; control bleeding source
type_specific_treatment.obstructive: Treat underlying cause: thrombolysis/embolectomy (PE), pericardiocentesis (tamponade), needle decompression (tension pneumo)

definition.@value: A classification system for circulatory failure based on underlying mechanism: distributive (vasodilatory), cardiogenic (pump failure), hypovolemic (volume depletion), and obstructive (mechanical obstruction)

scopeNote.@value: Foundational critical care concept for all shock management

learning_objectives: Define shock and its common cellular pathway
Classify shock into four mechanistic categories
Identify hemodynamic profiles distinguishing each shock type
Apply bedside assessment to determine shock type
Initiate type-specific treatment while addressing general resuscitation
clinical_pearls: Warm extremities + hypotension = distributive; cool extremities = cardiogenic or hypovolemic
JVD + hypotension + clear lungs = think obstructive (tamponade, massive PE)
Lactate clearance (>10%/2hr) is more important than absolute lactate for prognosis
Mixed shock is common - sepsis can cause both distributive AND cardiogenic
Shock index (HR/SBP) >0.9 predicts worse outcomes in trauma
common_misconceptions: Shock always means low blood pressure - BP can be normal early with compensatory mechanisms
All shock types need the same fluids - cardiogenic shock patients may worsen with fluids
Cool extremities always mean hypovolemia - could also be cardiogenic shock

evidence.confidence_rationale: Established pathophysiological classification with hemodynamic profiles
